description.text: litter clips, for holding the bag in the litterbox. Made with Tinkercad.

I'm making my own Air Hockey Table and the dog thinks the pucks are chew toys.  Once bitten they don't float so I ended up making my own.  Everything is completely parametric so you can experiment with whatever works best for you in terms of diameter and thickness.
Larger diameter pucks tend to float better because they have more air under them.  Play around with the thickness and size of the air gap until you have whatever works best for you.
This is also a really good test of your bridging, although nothing dramatic like the whistle it's still cool to watch it build.
Enjoy.
Try to print these at close to 100% fill.  Not so much for strength, but for mass.  Heavier things feel much better in the hand for handles and pucks are less likely to fly off the table.

description.text: This is a modular case for the LEDgoes Modular LED Matrix. (We're on Kickstarter right now at http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/558452768/ledgoes! Also at http://www.ledgoes.com) Each case encapsulates one Displayboard panel, and can daisy-chain together to mount a nice, long matrix. Each panel is about 1.5" x 2". This design is still experimental and needs some more mechanical tests. It also lacks mounting holes for wall mounts and, even though the cases feature lips to hold in the Displayboards, we want to put in extra holding pins to fully secure the Displayboards. Cases for double-row matrices (and beyond) will come later.

title: Universal 2204 Brushless Motor Gaurds (Scalable for any size motor)

This is a set of 4 different styles of universal brushless motor guards.

Original/Plain, Spiked, Flat Spike, and Sphere.

They will fit 2204 motors as is, but they will work for virtually any size of brushless motors. Just re-size/scale them to fit the motor size you want. The screw holes will fit any hole pattern on any motor.

Give your motors a better chance of surviving a crash. And you won't have to worrie about getting dirt and mud in them when you hit the ground.
I use these on every build now and I've only broke 1 guard since I've been using them.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in Hatchbox PLA with 3 layers top and bottom. The only hard part about the design is the curvature, and perhaps getting the port holes well formed if you have problems with your first layer sticking to the bed. Other than that the design should be pretty resilient to most changes you can make.

description.text:
I know what you're thinking, "Isn't a Zero a bit overkill for a clock?" For a normal clock, probably, but with the internet it can be so much more than a normal clock! You could make a clock that automatically adjusts across time zones based on it's IP address, or perhaps a clock to track your latest amazon order. For me, the clock tells me when the next subway train is coming at my stop. This is a relatively simple build that requires some soldering, but all off-the-shelf components.

BOM:

  • a 1.2" 7-segment display from Adafruit in whatever color you want
  • a Raspberry Pi Zero and supported power chord
  • some female to female jumper wires
  • a small wifi dongle, preferably one that you don't have to compile the module for (ahem)
  • (for the non press-fit version) 4 M2.5 screws and 3mm spacers

There are now two versions of the clock included: the original design features a removable backplate and requires some M2.5 screws and spacers, but results in a slightly more visually appealing clock as the seam is hidden at the back and on the corners and the layers are vertical. The press-fit clock requires no screws and features a bezel on the front of the clock, but the design has to be split horizontally instead of vertically.

If you are a better EE than I you could certainly buy just the display and some resistors and skip the I2c backpack altogether, opting for some protoboard or even posterboard to hold the display in. If you're going that far you could also snag a cheap one off Ebay or Alibaba and change the dimensions in the SCAD to fit.

Setting up a pi zero with wifi is a task in itself; I recommend snagging a starter kit if you don't have the requisite parts already and doing a NOOBS graphical installation. Doing a regular Raspbian installation over serial is also doable. I used wpa_supplicant for my Wifi configuration.

The pi zero can't support the amount of power a Wifi dongle draws over USB so you'll have to do this wifi patch hack to get it to run off the main USB power. This means you can't plug anything else into that USB port so be warned!

Notes:

Printed in Hatchbox PLA with 3 layers top and bottom. The only hard part about the design is the curvature, and perhaps getting the port holes well formed if you have problems with your first layer sticking to the bed. Other than that the design should be pretty resilient to most changes you can make.

As tight fitting designs are wont to do, my setup might not work on your machine. I highly recommend measuring your display and seeing how close the values are to the ones at the top of the SCAD file, regenerating as necessary, and if all else fails breaking out the X-acto knife and sandpaper and going to town.

You can follow this guide for a general how-to on enabling I2c and using the backpack with a raspberry pi. I've included pictures of the wire setup on this page, but for posterity purposes here they are:

  1. +5V and V_IC on the clock should go to 5v on the raspi, which are pins 2 and 4 according to this image
  2. GND should go to ground, which is pin 6
  3. SDA and SCL, the data and clock lines for I2c, need to go to the SDA and SCL GPIO pins on the pi, 3 and 5 respectively

Adafruit has a few example python scripts to get you started in the tutorial.

That should be it, let me know if you have any questions!

description.text:
Clean drinking water is a problem in many regions. The purpose of this device is to float on the surface of the water and collect the evaporated water, which would then be suitable for human consumption. The top cone section absorbs heat from the sun (that's why I printed it in black), and transfers this heat to the air captured between the structure and the water, as well as directly to the water itself. This heat encourages evaporation, which then will condense on the outer walls with the cooling fins, and then collect in the reservoir. Ideally there would also be some sort of convenient way to pour the collected water out, but I haven't settled on a great idea.
Additionally, the top of the water catcher can currently be used as a small cup, or to collect a limited amount of rain water.

Scale down to a size that will fit on your printer! This thing is designed to print standing straight up. Careful removing from the platform, because it is not the strongest structure ever, and the middle cone could disconnect from the outer ring.
I printed with ABS, which is what I had on hand. I drew my inspiration from thing #119674, which is a conical vapor collector, and the creator points out that ABS is not the best for working with something we will drink, so PLA would be better.

title: Uber 180 Remix - Standardized 10mm tubes - New Top/Bottom Plates

description.text:
I based my remix on the amazing design by theledman, here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1276783/

Please purchase the needed 10mm tubes from the link provided on his thing

I wanted to standardize the tubes used on this project so you only need to purchase one set of carbon tubes (about $20 on Amazon prime).

I created a new top and bottom plate based on the hardware I have on hand. There is a version of the top plate that will fit the ever popular HS1177 camera.

The new tube dimensions for this design are 4x114mm and 4x38mm. This will produce a 180mm frame that can fit 4" or 5" propellers.

EDIT 3/20/2016 - I have changed out the bottom plate to strengthen the connections, this changes the dimensions of the CF tubes. If you have the 'old' plate, you will need 4x115.5mm and 4x38.8mm to make a 180mm X frame. I do not have this part up for download any longer.

EDIT 3/25/2016 - I added a new low profile topplate design that should help protect your camera and hide it away in your build.

EDIT 5/12/2016 - I added another version of the above topplate, calling it the 'minimalist top plate' - simple with a cutout for a FPV camera and some areas to attach VTX and other hardware plus an antenna mounting location.

comments.text: ah... I was using Rhino3d (NURBS)... hmm... seeming like I can't quite remember the process and original is in my old backup files offline... I think you could take whatever shape you want and do an inside and outside path for the larger extrusion... and pull up your center curve to make a knife like edge... prob do the same with a single extrusion as well (inside follow and just taper one edge... maybe needs a blog entry... ok... figured it out again... take your outline path and make a 'v' shaped knife edge and do a sweep revolve (freeform) along the curve... you'll have to cap the planar hole (or sweep a triangle to start)...  that'll give you a nice cutting edge... it should be set to 90 deg on your curve you want to follow.... then extrude your larger offset edges that where made with your sweep rail to give your longer extrusion... if you want to you can do another offset on the end of that to make a nice base to grab a hold of as well as stiffen up the cutter.
comments.author: csomyy

comments.text: Thank you mate!
comments.author: wulfdesign

comments.text: Cookie cutter prints seem to come out better when the walls are the same width top to bottom.... trust me ive printed a few.    ~3mm wide has worked best for me, it doesnt come to a point but its still thin enough to easily make it through cookie dough

author: wulfdesign

description.text:
Since I made a new release of Banate CAD today:
http://williamaadams.wordpress.com/2011/11/28/banate-cad-second-release/ I thought I'd make somethingto to go with it. Well, while I was out in space taking pictures of the moon, and space ships, I thought, hay, why not turn the camera towards earth and take a couple of snaps, and create a model while I'm at it. This thing is a vector normal mapped (a new term I found on the internet) model of the earth. I grabbed a couple of high quality pictures from the internet, and just threw them into Banate CAD, the same way as I created the moon shot, and there you have it! I'm sure someone is dying to tell me the earth is an oblate spheroid, and that I can't model it strictly as a sphere, but I think at these sizes it won't really matter.

1) Print
2) Rule the Earth
3) Rejoice!

remixed_from.title: Reddit Alien - Two Part Easy Print

description.text:
This is a fun print that will sure be a great hit in your freezer. Simply fill the bottom half with water and then push the top half down, letting excess water drain out of the hole in the top. Make sure that the ridge on the bottom lines up with the indent on the top so that the snoos fit together. Once it is frozen, take the top off and flex the print to pop the alien out of the mold.

You could also use jello, frozen juice, frozen coffee, chocolate, candy, toothpaste, or anything else that appeals to you.

Flexible filament, this is your time to shine! With flexible filament, this print can have a tighter seal, while simultaneously making the alien easy to get out of the mold.

Printer:

Anything that can print with flexible filament

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Highly recommend printing with flexible filament.

If it's leaky, try reprinting the top around 1% larger, if it's too tight, 1% smaller.

Sanding is an option too, but make sure you wash any sanding residue off well before you make an ice alien.

This is a belt clip designed to mount on top of a 7" or 8" tablet case. The model is both the clip itself and a locking pin to hold the clip securely to the case. I used a 3/16" drill bit to tap the hole in the tablet case on a drill press. After tapping the hole the pin should slide snugly into place to secure the clip to the tablet case. I printed this model in ABS and used acetone to glue the lock pin in place but you could use super glue if printing with PLA.

These are the pod's I used.

title: Tool Holder for Wanhao Duplicator I3

description.text:
A simple tool holder for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 (version 2 definitely, could someone confirm version 1?). This also fits the Aldi Cocoon Create and I think the Monoprice version.

It holds a scraper, a 150mm steel rule, scalpel, wire cutters (flush cutters, whatever you call them) and 3 alan keys (2, 3 and 4mm),

My original m3 bolt didnt reach the thread in the frame, so I used a spare 12mm m3 bolt to join it.

description.text:
This is a very simple ring worn by the character Death The Kid from the anime Soul Eater. Not certain how well this will print as of yet - considering the thin triple bands that the ring normally has, I added supports between each in the hopes that it will help with stability. If you happen to print it, post an image and let me see how well it worked! Enjoy!

P.S. - since I have discovered that C4D doesn't do scaling very well at all, you will have to upscale the design for appropriate printing. 16 - 17mm for a size 7 ring...etc.
Simple C4D mockup.

title: Filament Funnel for SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V2

description.text:
After building my SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V2, I had trouble threading the filament through the top into the small hole and down to the cold end, It wasn't hard, just inconvenient to find the hole by touch since it was above my head.

I made this funnel to fit into the filament hole in the top of the bot and ease threading. The wide brim acts as a stabilizer so no need for any affix anything permanently.

I printed this using Simplify3D with support under the brim using PLA and a .2mm height.

description.text: My laptop has pretty poor circulation, so I wanted something to raise it up a bit so it can get better airflow. And rather than buying one, I decided to make one in just a few hours.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I left the shell thickness at the previous print's specifications, which I believe was 0.8 mm, but I would make it a bit thicker than that in the future.

One half printed in about 7 hours and 20 minutes.

Connecting the halves

I wanted to make this quickly and easily with the option of customizability and portability. With that in mind, I did not include any rods in the print. While not absolutely necessary, the addition of 1/4" wooden dowel rods or steel rod would strengthen the stand and give some additional weight to prevent tipping.

For larger laptops:

FYI: If you have a large laptop like mine, it might tip over when open, so scale it up if you can.

I have an 18.5" laptop, so I made a larger version of this but it didn't seem necessary to upload the new file because it was just scaled up.

I increased the scale of the length and height (X and Y, not Z) by 25% and left all other settings the same. The holes are now 5/16" in diameter. I don't have a printer large enough to test this, so I can't really tell you if it will work, but it should based on the measurements.
Added a window to the Openforge non edge 1x1 wall. Yes I used an archway and shrunk it down into a window.

description.text:
PRINT & SUPPORT! March is Endometriosis Awareness!
On March 25th (May 13th in Canada) there will be the World Wide Endo March!
https://endomarch.wordpress.com/team-international/

Did you just think "Endo What?"

Endometriosis hit at least 10% of world wide women, but being a commonly dismissed illness, it takes nearly a decade prior diagnosis.
Endometriosis is a systemic disease with numerous immune & endocrine malfunctions that sometime result in misplaced tissue, similar to the lining of the uterus, but not exactly the same, resulting in chronic pain and many other symptoms. It's also one of the lead causes of infertility and there is no definitive cure up to date.

Why is endometriosis awareness important?

  • Because many women are surrounded by family, friends and colleagues who don’t understand how profound the physical and emotional effects of endometriosis can be.
  • Because even after waiting an average of 7 to 9 years to get an endometriosis diagnosis, many women can't access effective treatment for endometriosis.
  • Because there is very little research on endometriosis, compared to other diseases with similar impacts.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This need to be printed in YELLOW, as it is the color for Endometriosis Awareness.

I permit Commercial use of this model in order to allow raising money for ENDOMETRIOSIS research, support and education in your country, but please, don't speculate on this model. It is already a very expensive illness right because it NEEDS more education and research.

You may print it smaller for a pendant, otherwise the current size is good for pins and keychains. You can highlight the text with a sharpie.

Spread Awareness!

Make photo of your print and share it (here and) on your social networks with #endomarch #endo or #endometriosis . Tag me @morenap3d

If you re in Canada you can also write your wish #awishnoted http://endometriosisnetwork.com/awishnoted/

Tinkercad info

You can personalize the ribbon with your own message in Tinkercad.
Please, keep it Endo related.
https://tinkercad.com/things/5wXO5qj24ZP and https://tinkercad.com/things/2lKkKPdwuHa

description.text:
This is a ring with hearts on the side. I made it in solid edge hence the .par file.  
This ring prints very fast and made an excellent thing to introduce the skeptical significant other to 3d printing with by having her watch the whole process.

This ring is sized to 19mm, I just experimented with the scaling in slic3r and printed a bunch of different sized rings scaled 100%-120% to find ones that fit.  
The hearts were easily visible even with 0.15-0.20mm layer height.

comments.text: This was the first "thing" I made on my PrintrBot Simple.  Worked great, and fit me perfectly! I used silver metallic sharpie to color the hearts so they stood out more. It's a great conversation piece.  Thank you!

title: Earring #80: SaTurn
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Oh yeah, here we go again.
I am not sure if this will be daily, and if so, CAN I just call it daily earring again?
Perhaps "DailyEarring2012" next year? :-) Anyway, this is a small Saturn, and the rings actually turn. Astronomy rules! :-)

Printing it in one go failed, there's just too much fill material, and making the gaps larger results in a loose fit.
Note that the axis is a bit short, so either extend it or add a bit of scrap plastic. I just removed the border of one of the half spheres.
Print, color, add a drop of insta-glue, done!
PP3DP UP settings/orientations see screenshots. Might work better with other support settings, the sphere without axis was hard to clean (perhaps via raft density?)

title: Mistborn Allomancy symbols for Combination Safe

description.text:
There's always another secret.

So this came about because I noticed there is a lack of anything Mistborn related here on thingiverse.com, plus I found this Combination Safe by SavageRodent. Several hours of work later and I had created 4 different rings filled with Allomantic Symbols that are compatible with SavageRodent's safe.

NOTE: For the rest of the files needed to build this Combination Safe please go to SavageRodent's original Thing. The only files hosted here are the rings with the Allomantic Symbols, intended to be used in place of SavageRodent's "Outer Ring" file.

Also, I scaled these to be the same size as SavageRodent's Cryptex's parts, but I recommend printing everything a little bigger, especially with the fine detail of some of the Allomancy symbols. I printed mine at 125% scale, and that worked great.

The Mistborn Novels

If you're not familiar with Mistborn, it is a series of Fantasy novels written by author Brandon Sanderson. I highly recommend that you check them out. Brandon Sanderson is known for writing fantasy novels that are very different from most Fantasy we're familiar with (i.e.: you won't find elves or dragons or wizards in his books). His worlds, characters, and magic systems are all very unique and engaging.

From his website, about the Mistborn books:

"Mistborn. A thousand years ago, the prophesied hero from lore rose up to overthrow a great and terrible evil. Only, he lost, and the Dark Lord took over and has been ruling with an iron fist for a thousand years. Ash falls from the sky in this barren land, and mists come every night, deep and mysterious. In this setting, a gang of thieves decides that the prophecies were all lies and that they can’t trust in some fabled hero to save them. They decide to take matters into their own hands, and plan a daring heist of the dark lord himself, planning to use the emperor’s own wealth to bribe his armies away from him and take over the empire."

The Allomantic Symbols

These symbols come from the Steel Alphabet- the writing system used in the Mistborn world. Every symbol in the Steel Alphabet corresponds to a Letter, a Number, and/or one of the metals used in the world's magic system, Allomancy. I have included a primer on how to read/write in the Steel Alphabet in the links. More and up-to-date information about the Steel Alphabet can be found here.

So I made 4 different rings, to accomodate a variety of the different symbols in the Steel Alphabet. Each symbol is featured at least once, and all the common symbols are featured more than once. Print out the rings you want and mix and match them to your hearts content.

Ring 1: Numbers

This ring contains the symbols used for numbers 0-9. The symbols on this ring are as follows:

Metal - Numeric Value - Letter/Sound

Unknown - 0 - none
Iron - 1 - B
Steel - 2 - P
Tin - 3 - E/I
Pewter - 4 - O/U
Zinc - 5 - L
Brass - 6 - R
Copper - 7 - D
Bronze - 8 - T
Cadmium - 9 - G

Ring 2: Basic Metals

This Ring contains the symbols for the metals commonly known during the Final Empire (Mistborn book 1).

The symbols on this ring are as follows:

Metal - Numeric Value - Letter/Sound

Iron - 1 - B
Steel - 2 - P
Tin - 3 - E/I
Pewter - 4 - O/U
Zinc - 5 - L
Brass - 6 - R
Copper - 7 - D
Bronze - 8 - T
Atium - unknown - V
Gold - 11 - M

Ring 3: Other Metals

This ring contains the symbols for the rest of the known metals. The symbols on this ring are as follows:

Metal - Numeric Value - Letter/Sound
Chromium - 13 - W
Nicrosil - 14 - Y
Aluminum - 15 - Z?
Duralumin - 16 - S
Cadmium - 9 - G
Bendalloy - 10 - K
Gold - 11 - M
Electrum - 12 - N
Lerasium - unknown - A
Malatium - unknown - F

Ring 4: Misc Symbols

This Ring contains symbols which have an alphabetic or numeric value, but don't have any known metals associated with them, as well as a few repeated symbols for common letters/sounds. The symbols on this ring are as follows:

Metal - Numeric Value - Letter/Sound
Unknown - 256 - J?
Unknown - 4096 - CH
Unknown - Unknown - H
Unknown - Unknown - SH
Lerasium - Unknown - A
Tin - 3 - E/I
Pewter - 4 - O/U
Gold - 11 - M
Electrum - 12 - N
Duralumin - 16 - S

There is no way I could have created this on my own, and a few people in particular deserve a special thanks.

  • Savage Rodent, for creating the Combination Safe in the first place.
  • jlatham, for posting a blank .stp version of the Outer Ring for easy editing.
  • Brandon Sanderson, for creating the incredibly deep and engaging Mistborn World.
  • All those who contributed to the Steel Alphabet article on the Coppermind Wiki.
  • Claincy Ffnord, for developing the Steel Alphabet font, which made creating these wheels far easier than it would have been otherwise.

And thanks to all of you for checking out my small contribution to this website! Feedback and criticisms are welcome!

I built a TV-B-Gone Kit and wanted a case for it. There are some here on Thingiverse but none that tickled my fancy.  
My design is a little different, that it has a momentary switch between the battery and the TV-B-Gone. When first powered on, the TV-B-Gone starts transmitting codes. When I press the momentary switch, power is applied to the board and it starts turning off TV's. When I let go, it stops (and the battery is no longer connected to the board).  
This case was printed out of ABS on an Afinia H Series printer.

Here are the parts you'll need:
-Printed top
-Printed bottom
-Dual AAA battery holder from Radio Shack
-Mini Momentary Switch from Radio Shack p/n 275-0003
-One of those screws that hold a CD Drive to your computer case First, print the two halves. I found it best to print them standing up on the back of the remote. Next, drill out the hole so that the switch shaft fits loosely in it. I left the hole a little small in the model so I could get a nice round hole by drilling it out. A 5/32 (0.156) inch bit worked great for me. I didn't do this but would next time: Glue the switch and battery holder into the top case first, then solder the connections. I used hot glue. The switch just interrupts the connection of the battery to the TV-B-Gone. Route the wires so that they won't interfere with the two halves coming together. The geometry of the case will hold the TV-B-Gone board and will not need glue. Put the halves together and secure with the screw. Turn off TVs!

comments.text: Very cool design... but doesn't fit my R 1.2 TV-B-Gone kit from Adafruit.  The newer version must have a different size board and uses 2 AA batteries vs. the 2 AAA batteries you are using.  They suggest using AA vs. AAA because of the amount of current the IR LEDs require.  I am going to modify this and will post a link once it is done...

Re-doing the master bathroom. The free standing bathtub from Maxx out of Canada uses 4 9/16" bolt heads as feet. I am planning to place the tub on a ceramic floor. This is a lot of weight for such a small pressure point as a bolt head. I designed a foot that is 1.75" on the tile side and the bolt head fits on the top side. Additionally I made a .0625" inset on the tile side so a 1.5" stick-on felt pad will be in-contact with the tile and held in place when sliding it in place. I hope this will soften the weight distribution.

When slicing, I set the object infill to 50% so there would be enough PLA to support the weight.

description.text:
Strait from the original movies, I submit the Belt Gizmo with the Nixie shelf! Print out with 10% infill without support with a layer height of .25 mm, unheated bed, with a speed of 50mm/s. The shelf on the Board should not be printed. The nixie shelf is designed for "homebrewing" the nixie tubes using 1/2" clear PVC tube (commonly used to make the leg hose for your costume).

Ive also uploaded this to Pinshape.com as an object for sale. If you like my work and would like to support me, please consider purchasing.

comments.text: When you say the "shelf on the board should not be printed" are you talking about that little flat raised bit that is attached to the main board that breaks off instantly once it's printed or something else?
comments.author: Predatormv

comments.text: Yeah - it was the placeholder and was designed to not be part of the final design - hence the Nixie shelf inclusion. you can still print it if you want to build off of it. Just to clarify there is a very small gap between the main board and the shelf component.

Facetime is fun, but after awhile the arm gets tired and the phone drifts down to chest height, giving your caller an unflattering view up your nose. This handle will help you keep the front camera closer to eye level without holding your hand in front of your face the whole time. The phone can tilt and swivel on the ball joint, and turn 90 degrees to one side for landscape view. If you want to put the phone down, you can convert the handle to a tabletop stand. The handle is built in 3 pieces that slide together and are held by a short length of shock cord (the kind used in tent poles). When you want to set the phone down, turn it sideways,then pull apart the handle pieces and arrange them in a triangle. The iPhone holder is sized to accommodate a Case-Mate which adds 4mm to the overall thickness of the phone. The vents on the front keep the speaker and microphone from being completely blocked by plastic. I'm thinking it might be fun to change the speaker opening to a socket which can take a phonecone (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6957). I haven't been able to try this out because my 3D printer hasn't arrived yet, but I would love some feedback. My biggest concern is the tension in the ball joint since there is a cut on one side to allow the ball to turn 90 degrees, which precludes wrapping a band around the socket to tighten it up. Perhaps a thin coat of plasti-dip can be used on the inside to add some friction. The conversion to tabletop stand would be easier to do if I used hinges. The hinges could be designed to only turn to one side, but there would need to be some way to lock them so the handle doesn't accidentally fold up while being held. The ball joint is from StefanHH (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5578) and the phone holder is derived from Jag's iPhone Wall Mount Dock (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7476).

Print the parts and glue the ball mount to the bottom of the iPhone holder.  Snap the ball into the socket, and tie a short length of shock cord to the eyelet on the bottom of the socket.  Run the cord through the handle pieces, and fit them together.  Pull the cord tight, tie it to the eyelet on the Handle 1 Cap, and cut off the excess.

print_settings.Notes:: One other point to consider is that the design assumes all cards are perfect and pristine. Over time, well used cards, particularly if un-sleeved, will tend to occupy more vertical space. The larger the deck, the more this will be noticed; so for Dominion, with a large deck of copper, the problem is fairly big. You can either sleeve your cards, which itself will require you to enter larger dimensions for both the cards and the thickness, or add a little to the width you specify for cards. Adding, say, 20%, to the card width should suffice for a long time.

description.text:
As this model deviates further from the original, I thought I'd release a v2 of it to keep things separate.

Changes from the original model include a configurable horizontal and vertical interlock system. I'll tweak this one eventually to allow a configurable finger access dimension, but for me these trays already work pretty well now.

The top/bottom interlocking let's you stack the trays when not in use. If you print one and stop the print process at 2mm, you will get a piece to fit on top. You can then wrap some elastic bands round the interlock system to keep everything together when not in use.

I've tried to comment the code well to both help me maintain it, give beginners some insight into how it works, and let other experienced coders snatch any part they want. I should also attribute the fillet formala used, which I didn't write. I think I got it from an OpenSCAD forum.

Printer:

e3d Bigbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I'm using a 0.4mm nozzle for the prints shown, all of which are printed in PLA.

I recommend you use the customizer to design a small test square shape for, say, 10 cards, as your first test. Print two and test the fit with relation to how they interlock, both one on top of each other and side to side and end on. If they're too loose, then adjust the sideInterlock distance upward (max is really 2-nozzle thickness, but that assume a perfectly accurate printer that makes perfect pointed corners). I find 1.1 to be a pretty tight fit. 0 would be zero interlock. So if you find the fit is too tight, adjust downward.

One other point to consider is that the design assumes all cards are perfect and pristine. Over time, well used cards, particularly if un-sleeved, will tend to occupy more vertical space. The larger the deck, the more this will be noticed; so for Dominion, with a large deck of copper, the problem is fairly big. You can either sleeve your cards, which itself will require you to enter larger dimensions for both the cards and the thickness, or add a little to the width you specify for cards. Adding, say, 20%, to the card width should suffice for a long time.

comments.text: When you stack these, are they locked together, or just sat on top of each other?
comments.author: inches

comments.text: When they're stacked, they're not firmly locked. The locking is a horizontal mechanism. Printing a "lid" adds both an aesthetic quality and a protective quality, but doesn't aid locking. The design is made with an elastic band in mind for the "lock" when stacked. You can then transport the stack with the band and store that in your box. Hope that helps.
comments.author: inches

comments.text: I'm curious how difficult it would be to provide a 'tabbed' cover? Taller configurations tend to be a bit flexible and I've found a hand-modified tabbed cover helps keep everything rigid. Perhaps it's outside the spirit of the project (shorter interlocking trays), but maybe it would be handy? I'm looking to tackle OpenSCAD soon enough and can probably figure it out, but I thought it might be worth asking :). You can see an example of what I'm talking about over at my remix of this project, in the second photo: Tabbed covers.
comments.author: WardF

comments.text: I've updated the model so that you now have an option (defaulted to on) to produce a locking lid. I reused the interlock system I designed so that the tabs mesh. As with the tray interlocks, you can control the tightness of the fit by adjusting topBottomInterlockClearance, which defaults to allow easy motion and give some leeway for less accurate machines. I'd love to get your feedback on whether these work for you.
comments.author: WardF

comments.text: Thank you very much! I will try some new prints this evening and will report back how things work.
comments.author: SpoonUnit

comments.text: I see what you mean. Presumably the corners become a little movable with tall towers. Adding an option to include auto generated tabs shouldn't be too much of a problem. I'll see what I can do.
comments.author: WardF

comments.text: Do you have the file for the red cover showing on the main image?
comments.author: Schaumbee

comments.text: ok - new version uploaded - there's an option at the bottom that lets you select "lid only"
comments.author: Schaumbee

comments.text: interesting ... looks like I already did provide this option, I wonder if I didn't upload it
comments.author: Schaumbee

comments.text: It's just really a print of the same thing, but stopped before the sides build. I should really alter the scad file so that you can choose that, as ideally you need it sized as per your selected dimensions. I'll sort that out for you.

description.text: https://b2b.partcommunity.com/community/partcloud/index#!part?name=Thrust+tappered+%2F+Cylindrical+roller+bearing&model_id=41703

Made to hold a 60-card deck, fits perfectly.

Will check dovetail tolerances as soon as I print another, this model was printed at 0% fill with 1 shell to check dimensions, but it's perfectly serviceable. I'd print with 2 shells for a less flimsy build.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1407527

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1407527

Using the following options:

filletSize = 8
cardWidth = 63
numberOfCards = 60
interlockClearance = -1.1
cardHeight = 88
topBottomInterlockClearance = 0.5
totalCardDepth = 0.3
baseEdgeThickness = 7
zSpace = 2.5
xySpace = 2

comments.text: Presumably these are un-sleeved cards? Would love to see your print when it completes :). Now, which colour deck could you be making this for ...
comments.author: SpoonUnit

comments.text: Yes, this will be for unsleeved cards, mostly just deck and graveyard, will probably rescale the height for the graveyard (shorter).  And it will be for my black deck of doom! ;)  Will post a pic when I can!
comments.author: SpoonUnit

comments.text: Ha. I love getting lots in the graveyard and then making it EMERGE :). I wonder if you'll be printing this in bright pink then ... hmmm .... maybe not ;)
comments.author: Drago3000

comments.text: So, a test on 1 shell, 0% fill - cards fit perfectly.  I have another coming off soon to check for interlocking.
comments.author: SpoonUnit

comments.text: Looks like a really close fit though. Did you measure the cards? I noticed you put in 2mm for xySpace, which should give a little play with the cards and reduce wear on unsleeved cards (I'm also an un-sleever :) )
comments.author: Drago3000

comments.text: Yeah I measured the cards (with a mm ruler, not a caliper - so not as exact as I could have been) and the 2mm gap ended up printing at around a 1mm gap on top and bottom with the cards aligned to one corner, so a .5mm gap on all sides.  They are not as tight as they look, and don't stick or rub when removed.  I do wonder about how much room will remain if I up it to 2 layers though.  Only one way to find out!
comments.author: SpoonUnit

comments.text: If they don't stick or rub, that's the key. The original model I took was fitting the cards to within a nano meter, so they were hard to remove. Of course, that could have been the inaccuracy of my old printer too. Writing the design as code though means you can custom fit this to any card, for any game. Well, I say that, but really I mean rectangular cards :).
comments.author: Drago3000

description.text: This is a tower we use as houses for Harry Potter Monopoly

To be mounted at the top of a Flux 3DP.
When using a Flux, but not the Printing head, you can place the head in the holder with the feed tube still attached (so head is turned upside down when not in use) instead of having to disassemble/ reassemble every time.
The top portion should clip over the top edge of the club and rest on top of the filament holder lid.
Yet to try it myself while I'm getting through setting up my printer but will upload pics when I eventually get round to making one.

Comments/ feedback welcome.

Update: 11/5/16 - Added a simplified version to reduce print times and can be printed on its side and without need for supports.

Cheers,
David
